awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Nutrient-mediated Manipulation of Host Feeding Behavior by a Parasitoid
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how an animal's nutrient intake affects its interaction with its parasites.  Using an experimentally tractable model system of a caterpillar and its parasitic wasp, Dr. Singer and Ms. Bernardo will conduct experiments designed to reveal how the parasitic wasp benefits by manipulating its host caterpillar's highly regulated nutrient intake.  The basic scientific value of this research stems from integrating the perspectives of animal nutrition, immunology, and behavioral ecology, while also contributing to scientific knowledge used in pest control in agriculture and forestry. Public outreach impacts will happen through Elementary Schools in Middlesex County, CT, and Ms. Bernardo's position as vice-president of the Connecticut Entomological Society.  The school program will highlight the natural history of insects kept in the lab, while the CT Entomological Society program will organize outreach activities for Connecticut residents of all ages and provide opportunities for other students to share their research with the community at an annual Student Symposium.

Parasitoids must battle host defenses and alter the behavior and physiology of their hosts to their own benefit.  Parasitoid manipulation of host nutrient intake might be a fundamental component of such interactions, yet it has received limited study in the broader field of host-parasite interactions. This research will test alternative functional hypotheses that could explain manipulation of caterpillar host feeding behavior by a parasitoid wasp.  Preliminary evidence from this host-parasitoid interaction suggests that host caterpillars exhibit altered nutrient intake when parasitized by the parasitoid wasp, and this change in host feeding behavior benefits the parasitoid.  Hypothetically, altering dietary nutrients of the host can have large effects on parasitoid growth performance and host immune function.  Consequently, parasitoids could manipulate host nutrient intake so as to maximize the nutrient supply to host tissues eaten by the parasitoid, or to limit nutrients required for maximal host immune function.  The researchers propose to manipulate macronutrient ratios in host diets and use techniques employed in the field of ecoimmunology and insect physiology to evaluate these hypothetical mechanisms of nutrient-mediated host manipulation, and their possible interaction. Data from this project will be stored at Wesleyan University and made accessible as published.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

The research component of the project aims to understand how and why parasites manipulate the feeding behavior of their hosts. Our review of this field of study revealed that there were no clear criteria that could establish definitive cases of parasite-manipulation of host feeding behavior. In our first publication from this project, we developed such criteria: 1) feeding behavior of parasitized hosts differs from that of unparasitized hosts, 2) the parasite-altered feeding behavior is physiologically regulated, 3) the parasite-altered feeding behavior increases parasite fitness at the expense of host fitness. Criterion 2, which distinguishes adaptive from non-adaptive processes, had not previously been integrated with the others. Our first round of experiments found evidence supporting these three criteria and showed that the parasite we studied manipulates the nutrient intake of its caterpillar host. To our knowledge, this is one of the first definitive cases of parasite-manipulation of host feeding behavior, and the only known case of manipulation of host nutrient intake. More specifically, we found that parasitized caterpillars showed a distinctive pattern of nutrient intake compared to unparasitized controls, and this altered diet of the host increased the growth of developing parasites. Our second set of experiments found evidence that the parasite not only manipulates the host?s nutrient intake but also its allocation of lipids to the host?s fat body, which is the tissue that the developing parasites rely on for growth. Our third set of experiments show that the manipulation of host behavior and physiology by the parasite delays the recovery of the host immune response, providing an improved opportunity for the developing parasitoids to avoid the host?s immune response.

 

Broader impacts

This project facilitated professional development for all participants. For PI Singer, this project has expanded his research program into the field of parasite manipulation of hosts. For PI Bernardo, the project has provided training in experimental research methods and undergraduate mentorship. Development of these skills prepared PI Bernardo for her current position as a member of the science faculty at The Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, CT. While there, she has developed lab experiments for her Biology curriculum, started a research-based Tropical Ecology Program, and also advises a set of students. The undergraduate research assistants received training in laboratory techniques and research experience that contribute to their future career paths and employment success. The other major broader impact component was educational outreach. We hosted fifth graders from Wilbert Snow Elementary School in Middletown, CT for a tour of our research lab. Many were excited by the opportunity to learn about caterpillars and their parasitic wasps during show-and-tell sessions. Several students wrote thank-you cards with illustrations. In addition, PI Bernardo currently teaches high school students about the process and value of biological research, drawing on examples that include the methods and findings of this project.
